user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_file_size:
```c
lfs_soff_t lfs_file_size(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_file_size(%p, %p)", (void*)lfs, (void*)file);
    LFS_ASSERT(lfs_mlist_isopen(lfs->mlist, (struct lfs_mlist*)file));

    lfs_soff_t res = lfs_file_size_(lfs, file);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_file_size -> %"PRIu32, res);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return res;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_file_size:
typedef struct lfs {
    lfs_cache_t rcache;
    lfs_cache_t pcache;

    lfs_block_t root[2];
    struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    } *mlist;
    uint32_t seed;

    lfs_gstate_t gstate;
    lfs_gstate_t gdisk;
    lfs_gstate_t gdelta;

    struct lfs_lookahead {
        lfs_block_t start;
        lfs_block_t size;
        lfs_block_t next;
        lfs_block_t ckpoint;
        uint8_t *buffer;
    } lookahead;

    const struct lfs_config *cfg;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
    lfs_size_t inline_max;

#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE
    struct lfs1 *lfs1;
#endif
} lfs_t
...
typedef struct lfs_file {
    struct lfs_file *next;
    uint16_t id;
    uint8_t type;
    lfs_mdir_t m;

    struct lfs_ctz {
        lfs_block_t head;
        lfs_size_t size;
    } ctz;

    uint32_t flags;
    lfs_off_t pos;
    lfs_block_t block;
    lfs_off_t off;
    lfs_cache_t cache;

    const struct lfs_file_config *cfg;
} lfs_file_t
...
struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    }
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I flagged the function parameter declaration and the places where pointers are cast/used because they may be eligible for const qualification or may be masking constness via casts and should be investigated. I did not flag other pointer-containing fragments because: - Fields already declared const (e.g. const struct lfs_config *cfg; const struct lfs_file_config *cfg;) are correctly const-qualified. - Pointer fields that represent mutable linked-list or cache state (e.g. next pointers, caches, ctz members, flags, position/offset fields) are typically intended to be modified and therefore should not be made const. - Macro usage that takes the existing cfg pointer (LFS_LOCK/LFS_UNLOCK) and printing casts to (void*) for logging are idiomatic and do not by themselves indicate missing const qualification. Based on the provided code, the listed fragments are the places most likely to deserve review for Rule 8.13; other pointer usages appear to either already be const or appropriately mutable.
